title-group.article-title: Exploring the equitable inclusion of diverse voices in urban green design, planning and policy development: a scoping review protocol

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Despite the increasingly evidenced positive impacts of green space on human physical and mental health, green spaces remain inequitably distributed across different socioeconomic groups. Urban planning and design should prioritise the development and maintenance of urban green spaces, especially for vulnerable and marginalised populations while thinking about protecting them from the effects of green gentrification. This scoping review will explore how the concepts of equity, diversity and inclusion are integrated into the design, the planning and policy development of urban green spaces. Also, we will explore what are the efforts made to incorporate equity, diversity, and inclusion concepts into the planning, design and policy development of urban green spaces to make them equitable for vulnerable and marginalised populations.

sec.title: Methods and analysis
sec.p: This protocol is based on the methodology developed by Arksey and O’Malley and improved by Levac et al. The search will be done in conjunction with a professional librarian, to include studies in all languages. The review will include multidisciplinary databases: Ovid MEDLINE, Ovid EMBASE, CINAHL, Web of Science and GeoBase. The search will be done from each database’s inception to February 2024. We will present our results narratively and will conduct a thematic analysis using the urban green equity framework. This framework will guide our understanding of the interplay between the spatial distribution of urban green spaces and the recognition of diverse voices in urban greening decision-making.

sec.title: Ethics and dissemination
sec.p: This scoping review will not require ethical approval since it will be collected from publicly available documents. The results of this scoping review will be presented as a scientific article, social media and public health or environmental conferences organised by environmental organisations or academic institutions.

caption.title: STRENGTHS AND LIMITATIONS OF THIS STUDY

list-item.p: To our knowledge, this will be the first scoping review exploring which and how the concepts of equity, diversity and inclusion are integrated into the design, the planning and policy development of urban green spaces.
This review will explore articles from interdisciplinary databases.

This review will not use language restrictions during the search strategy, thereby reducing the risk of publication bias and providing the opportunity to include studies from diverse cultures and contexts.
This team includes researchers from multiple disciplines (social sciences and health sciences).
This review will only include data from scientific databases; therefore, it will not capture information outlined in organisational documents publicly available in other sources.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Globally, 70% of the population is expected to live in urban settlements by 2050.1 Urban settlements increase mortality risk factors such as non-communicable chronic diseases24 and favour the development of anxiety, depression and stress related to factors such as overcrowding, social isolation and limited access to green spaces and recreational areas.57Across the world, many urban settlements are vulnerable to climate change and the health risks it poses to their populations through effects such as floodings, heat islands and the increase of vectorborne diseases.8 9 In a context of climate change and urban sprawl, strategies for developing green spaces must play an important role in land-use planning.

Urban green spaces ‘include parks, green areas or green spaces for sports and physical activities, urban forests as well as greenery in streets and private and semi-private spaces. Community gardens are also included in this definition’.10 Green spaces can be (1) public spaces (eg, parks, greenways, conservation areas, community gardens, school grounds, etc) or (2) private and institutional spaces and infrastructure (eg, gardens, green roofs, green walls, cemeteries and other outdoor spaces).1113 The 2030 agenda for sustainable development establishes 17 sustainable development goals.14 Goal 11, aims to ‘make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient and sustainable’. Protecting, upgrading and increasing urban and peri-urban green spaces is fundamental for the sustainable development of urban areas that represent the goods and services provided by nature to humans.1518

Urban green spaces have positive impacts on human well-being and physical and mental health.1930 But above all, green spaces are valuable for adapting to the emerging and irreversible impacts of climate change (eg, mitigate air pollution by absorbing and filtering pollutants, reduce urban heat islands by creating shade or cool zones).31 32 Green spaces serve as gathering places for communities, promoting social interaction, social cohesion and reducing social isolation.33 They provide relief from stress and improves mental health and well-being (restoration).3437

Despite the listed benefits from green spaces, evidence describe the insufficient and inequitable distribution of green spaces within vulnerable and marginalised populations.3848 Research have shown a consistent trend that race, ethnicity, lower education level41 49 and lower socioeconomic status play a major role in decreasing health and well-being of members of disadvantaged communities.5059 Urban green spaces play a crucial role in promoting health and well-being of urban residents.55 60 They are a link between human beings and nature that all citizens should equitably benefit from, however, urban planners and policy makers struggle to distribute urban green spaces evenly.456163

Research suggests that inequitable access to urban green spaces is an environmental justice issue that contributes to social exclusion.57646970 Urban green spaces are increasingly gaining importance among public health professionals, environmental justice advocates and scholars due to the increased awareness about the public health and environmental benefits that urban green spaces can bring to neighbourhoods and cities.45

To maximise the benefits of green spaces, urban planning and design should prioritise the development, the maintenance, the preservation and the restoration of green spaces, especially in vulnerable and marginalised communities. Inclusion is the practice of using proactive measures to create an environment where people feel equally welcomed, supported, respected and valued, and to foster a sense of belonging and engagement. It is also important to recognise that many individuals have multiple social, economic, racial or sexual identities and often face increased discrimination or systematic barriers based on their intersecting identities.71 72 Diversity refers to the variety of people identities found within an organisation, group or society.71 72

Equity refers to the ability of individuals, groups, communities and populations to have a fair chance to reach their full health potential.73 Including the diverse local communities’ voices in the design and management of urban green space has been found to have positive effects on social cohesion and to promote the use of urban green spaces.48 55 60 74 However, socially disadvantaged groups, such as racial and ethnic minorities, low-income individuals, older adults and people with disabilities, are less likely to use urban green spaces and tend to live in communities that have few urban green spaces.47 64 75 76 Furthermore, inequitable access to urban green spaces has been associated with limited opportunities for disadvantaged groups to benefit from the health and social advantages that urban green spaces offer, a situation often referred to as environmental injustice.45 77 78

But there is scarce data on how concepts of equity, diversity and inclusion (EDI) are applied to community local voices and how these concepts are considered in making urban green spaces equitable for vulnerable and marginalised populations. We will conduct a scoping review to explore how the concepts of EDI are integrated into the design, the planning and policy development of urban green spaces. Also, we will explore what are the efforts made to incorporate EDI concepts into the planning, design and policy development of urban green spaces to make them equitable for vulnerable and marginalised populations.

To be able to grasp the complexity of equitable access to urban green spaces among vulnerable and marginalised populations, we will use the urban green equity framework, developed by Nesbitt et al.79 The urban green equity framework79 will help us to understand the interplay between the spatial distribution of urban green spaces and the inclusion of diverse voices in urban greening planning and decision making, defined as acknowledgement of participants’ existence and validity in decision-making processes. Furthermore, the urban green equity framework will provide an equity lens to analyse urban green spaces design, planning and policy development contribute to maintain the marginalisation of vulnerable social groups, to favour environmental injustice and privileged communities.79

The results of this study should help identify issues and opportunities related to the creation of urban green spaces interventions and policies under the scope of EDI of vulnerable and marginalised populations. This study could also inform the efforts of academic institutions and environmental organisations to promote education, research and policy initiatives at the municipal and state levels aimed at fostering equitable urban planning.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: The concepts of EDI are relevant in the literature but still underexplored when considering the design, planning and policy development of urban green spaces to make them equitable for vulnerable and marginalised populations. We deemed it appropriate to conduct a scoping review to examine the extent and nature of the existing research on urban planning EDI, with a focus on how vulnerable and marginalised voices are considered during the development and planning of urban green spaces. This review will help us to identify gaps in the existing body of literature. With this methodology, we will be able to summarise and disseminate information regarding the current practices during the planification and the development of urban green spaces interventions and policies. Furthermore, our results will be presented through the lens of EDI, which will help academics, environmental organisations and policy makers give greater consideration to these aspects in urban green spaces planning, decision-making and in determining future research priorities on this subject.

This protocol presents the methodology for conducting a scoping review. This scoping review will be based on the methodology developed by Arksey and O’Malley80 and improved by Levac et al.81 Additionally, we will follow the reporting guidelines from the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analyses extension for Scoping Reviews. We will adhere to the six stages of scoping review methodologies, as described below.

sec.title: Stage 1: identification of the research questions
sec.p: The questions addressed in this scoping review are:
Which EDI concepts have been integrated into the design, planning and policy development of urban green spaces?

How have EDI concepts been actioned in the planning, design and policy development of urban green spaces? This question examines the specific efforts and processes through which EDI concepts have been implemented.

At what stages (design, planning or policy development) were EDI concepts incorporated into urban green spaces? This new question addresses when EDI concepts were included, providing insights into the stages of integration.

sec.title: Stage 2: identifying relevant studies
sec.p: The search strategy will be designed and conducted iteratively by an experienced librarian (LJP) with input from the study’s principal investigators (TD, SD). The search will be conducted without language restrictions. The search will include these interdisciplinary databases: Ovid MEDLINE and Epub Ahead of Print, In-Process and Other Non-Indexed Citations and Daily, Ovid EMBASE, CINAHL, Web of Science and GeoBase. The search will be done from each database’s inception to February 2024.
Concepts guiding the keyword selection for the search strategy will be as follows:

Urban green spaces (concept 1): ‘urban green spaces include parks, green areas for green spaces for sports and physical activities, urban forests as well as greenery in streets and private and semi-private spaces. Community gardens are also included in this definition’.10

Vulnerable populations (concept 2): ‘are individuals who are at greater risk of poor physical and social health status. They are considered vulnerable because of disparities in physical, economic and social health status when compared with the dominant population’.73
Marginalised populations (concept 3): ‘a group of people that is excluded from full and meaningful participation in society, typically through discrimination or other means of oppression’.73

Inclusion (concept 4): the practice of using proactive measures to create an environment where people (eg, under-represented groups—women, racialised minorities, Indigenous people, persons with disabilities and members of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, two-spirit, plus feel equally welcomed, supported, respected and valued, and to foster a sense of belonging and engagement.71 72

Diversity(concept 5): the variety of identities (differences in race, colour, place of origin, religion, immigrant and newcomer status, ethnic origin, ability, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, gender expression and age) found within an organisation, group or society.71 72

Equity(concept 6): ‘the ability of individuals, groups, communities and populations to have a fair chance to reach their full health potential’.73 To achieve this, institutions must proactively identify and address systemic barriers in their policies and work environments (eg, racism, ableism, sexism, discrimination).72

Controlled vocabulary supplemented with keywords will be used to search for the inclusion of EDI concepts for urban green spaces design, planning and policy development, and, to search for the efforts done to include EDI when making urban green spaces equitable for marginalised and vulnerable populations. The professional librarian will do trial runs of the search with different subsets of key terms, later we will have discussions between the different co-authors to reach the final version of the search. The complete search strategy is included in online supplemental appendix 1. An example of the Web of Science search strategy is shown in table 1.

caption.title: Example of a search strategy in Web of Science

sec.title: Stage 3: study selection
sec.p: We will use the reference management software EndNote V.20 to download abstracts from each database, which we will then be transferred to the systematic review management online software Covidence to eliminate the duplicates from the search results. Then, we will perform an abstract screening pilot (1% of the total number of titles and abstracts) on a random set of search results to test our inclusion and exclusion criteria (box 1). This will ensure we establish strong inter-rater reliability among reviewers (minimum 75%). Next, two reviewers (NRES, SD) will independently screen titles and abstracts against the inclusion and exclusion criteria. Any disagreement regarding inclusion or exclusion will be resolved by consensus by the members of the research team (TD and FD). Two reviewers will then independently conduct the full-text review on all studies included in the previous phase. Two reviewers (TD and FD) will solve any conflicts regarding the eligibility of studies during the full-text review phase. Articles in languages other than English, French, Spanish or Portuguese (these are the languages the study team are fluent in) will be read and translated using Google translate (during abstract and title screening and full-text screening), an effective tool used in previous reviews.82 During the full-text review, the researchers will search within the reference lists, of included full-text articles, to find additional potential studies to include in the review. The research team will perform a forward citation search to identify recent publications on a similar topic that have cited our selected articles. Once we identify new titles during the reference search, we will add them to the study corpus and, we will evaluate them following the same previous steps. The selection process will be done in Covidence software.

boxed-text.label: Box 1
boxed-text.p: Study selection will be based on the following inclusion and exclusion criteria:

list-item.p: The article is an empirical study (qualitative or quantitative), a conceptual paper, a discussion paper or a peer-reviewed editorial, AND,
The study focuses on the planning, design and policy development of urban green spaces that integrate the concepts of inclusion, diversity and equity, OR,

The study describes how equity, diversity and inclusion concepts were included during the planning, design and policy development of urban green spaces to make them equitable to vulnerable and marginalised populations.

The study focuses on urban green spaces interventions for the general population, without using an equity, diversity or inclusion lens for the design, planning or policy development of the urban green spaces, OR,

The study does not describe how equity, diversity and inclusion concepts were included during the planning, design and policy development of urban green spaces to make them equitable to vulnerable and marginalised populations.

sec.title: Stage 4: charting the data
sec.p: The research team will use the systematic review management online software Covidence to develop a descriptive data-charting form to extract relevant information to answer our research questions. Box 2 includes the data to be extracted during the data extraction phase. To assure the rigour during the extraction process, data will be extracted by a single researcher (NRES or FD) but will be double checked by a senior researcher in the team (SD or TD). Moreover, regular team meetings will be held to solve conflicts during the data extraction phase and to ensure timely progress.

boxed-text.label: Box 2
boxed-text.p: Equity, diversity and inclusion, interventions’ components

sec.title: Stage 5: collating, summarising and reporting results
sec.p: We will follow a multistep plan to collate, summarise and report the results. The abstract and title screening phase will start in June 2024, followed by full-text screening in July 2024. Data extraction and data cleaning will take place in August and September 2024. Data analysis will start from September and October 2024. The scoping review, including the consultation step, is expected to be completed by December 2024.

Descriptive data from the included articles will be summarised in an extraction form elaborated in Microsoft Excel. Our analysis will be guided by the urban green equity framework, developed by Nesbitt et al.79 We selected this framework because of the relevance of its two dimensions. First, a spatial distribution of urban vegetation, acknowledges that the spatial distribution of urban vegetation in relation to residents’ homes and places of work influences whether residents have opportunities to access urban vegetation and how often that access occurs. The dimension contains four principal subdimensions presented here: (1) temporality (social and biophysical legacies, the availability of leisure time in which to access urban vegetation and the availability of urban vegetation related to seasonality), (2) condition (condition of urban trees and parks, condition of urban parks facilities), (3) preference (preferences may influence residents’ choices to access urban vegetation and their experiences while accessing it, thereby influencing residents’ experiences of distributional equity) and (4) ownership (influences whether residents can access and benefit from urban vegetation near their home or work). Second, the recognition in urban vegetation decision-making involves both access to and influence within formal and informal decision-making processes. This dimension has four principal subdimensions: (1) representation (inclusion of individuals to be present and have power within the decision-making process in order to influence the process and its outcomes), (2) procedure (process must fairly consider and respect the voices of participants to achieve procedural equity and thus recognition for all participants), (3) desire to participate (motivation to participate in decision-making) and (4) ability to participate (stewardship opportunities, public meetings, community advisory bodies or resistance-based action must be structured in such a way as to allow for residents of variable incomes, schedules, language abilities and cultural backgrounds to participate).

This framework will help us identify the factors that influence the consideration of vulnerable and marginalised populations in the planning, design and policy development of urban green spaces. This framework will help us understand the considerations needed to make urban green spaces available and accessible to these populations. Additionally, it helps us determine if urban green space development is tailored to the needs of vulnerable and marginalised populations. Ultimately, the interaction of both dimensions and the social and environmental scope of this framework will help us analyse the influence of local contexts and the role of cultural and institutional inequity in the development of urban green spaces.

Furthermore, the urban green equity framework will provide an equity lens to analyse how urban green space design, planning and policy development may contribute to the marginalisation of vulnerable social groups, favour environmental injustice and privileged communities.79

Two reviewers (SD, NRES) will review, interpret and independently code the relevant data in the qualitative analysis software NVivo. Also, the data related to the integration of EDI concepts into the design, planning and policy development of urban green spaces will be analysed using thematic analysis approach by Thomas and Harden.83 This will help us move beyond mere data descriptions to infer new insights and identify gaps regarding the inclusion of EDI concepts in making urban green spaces equitable for vulnerable and marginalised populations. The researchers will independently develop inductive themes, which will then be refined through group discussions. The findings will be presented to the entire research team who will critique the findings. We will not include the quality assessment of our selected studies, as suggested by Arksey and O’Malley and Levac et al. However, we will recognise it as a limitation of the method. This means our data interpretation might be open to bias.

sec.title: Consultation
sec.p: During the consultations, we will share key findings with different stakeholders (eg, researchers in the field, non-profit organisation Nature Quebec, Quebec National Institute of Public Health, Vivre en Ville and the Montréal Urban Ecology Centre) to obtain feedback on the presentation and interpretation of the study results. This step will help us to identify knowledge transfer opportunities.

sec.title: Patient and public involvement
sec.p: Patients and/or the public were not involved in the design, or conduct, or reporting, or dissemination plans of this research.

sec.title: Strengths and limitations
sec.p: This scoping review will have several strengths. First, this review will entail a rigorous search strategy of the literature developed by a professional librarian (LJP). Second, this review will be conducted by multiple researchers, enhancing its quality. Third, our team includes an interdisciplinary group of researchers to consider multiple perspectives and to limit the risk of bias. Fourth, this review will not be restricting the search strategy by language, thereby it will reduce the risk of publication bias and will provide the opportunity to include studies from diverse cultures and contexts. Fifth, we will consult with different partners and primary users of this work. This review will also have limitations. First, our review will be limited to the scientific literature available in scientific databases; thus, it will not capture information outlined in organisational documents publicly available in other sources. Second, while using Google Translate to include articles in languages other than English, Spanish, French or Portuguese will enable us to include them in the review, there is a risk of inaccuracies in the translated material.

sec.title: Ethics and dissemination
sec.p: This scoping review does not require ethical approval since it will be collected from publicly available documents. We will produce a scientific article for publication in a journal related to the field and share the published article results on social media platforms (eg, LinkedIn). We will share our findings in local events for lay and public audiences, researchers, local authorities and health services administrators (eg, community events). Scoping review results will also be presented at public health or environmental workshops, research webinars and public health or environmental conferences organised by healthcare organisations (eg, organisations under the authority of the environment ministry of Quebec: James Bay Advisory Committee on the Environment, Minister of the Environment, the Fight Against Climate Change, Wildlife and Parks, Environmental and Social Impact Review Panel (COFEX), Advisory Committee on Climate Change) or academic institutions (eg, medicine faculty and public health programme of Laval University). Finally, findings from this scoping review will set the base for developing empirical studies specifically addressing the knowledge gaps identified from our analysis.

fn.p: Funding: This work was supported by the Faculty of Nursing Sciences at Laval University (SAR- AP527151). TD received support from Quebec Population Health Research Network (SR138986).
Prepublication history and additional supplemental material for this paper are available online. To view these files, please visit the journal online (https://doi.org/10.1136/bmjopen-2023-078396).
Provenance and peer review: Not commissioned; externally peer reviewed.
Patient consent for publication: Not applicable.
Patient and public involvement: Patients and/or the public were not involved in the design, or conduct, or reporting, or dissemination plans of this research.
